details.title: Comparison of the Mean Time Between Failures for Two Systems Under Short Tests
details.standardTitle: Comparison of the Mean Time Between Failures for Two Systems Under Short Tests

p: Yefim Haim Michlin (M'07–SM'07) is a Senior Researcher in Quality Assurance and Reliability at the Technion. He obtained the Ph.D. (1980) in statistical dynamics of machines. He worked from 1973 to 1990 at the Tashkent State Polytechnic University (Associate Professor). Since 1991, he has been teaching at the Technion (Reliability Engineering). He is a Senior Member of the IEEE Reliability Society.

authors.affiliation: Fac. of Ind. Eng. &. Manage., Technion - Israel Inst. of Technol., Haifa, Israel
authors.name: Yefim H. Michlin

p: Genady Ya. Grabarnik (M'07–SM'07) received his Ph.D. in Mathematics-Physics from the Institute of Mathematics, Uzbek Academy of Sciences, in 1987. He is a Researcher at the IBM T. J. Watson Research Center in Hawthorne, NY. His research interests include operator algebras, statistics, automated planning, data mining, and computer systems. He is a Senior Member of the IEEE Reliability Society.

authors.affiliation: T.J. Watson Res. Center, IBM, Hawthorne, NY, USA
authors.name: Genady. Ya. Grabarnik

p: Elena Leshchenko received the M.Sc. in Applied Mathematics at the Chelyabinsk Technical University (USSR) in 1991; the M.Sc. in Quality Assurance and Reliability at the Technion in 2007; and is now working at the Technion Research and Development Foundation, Haifa, Israel

authors.affiliation: Fac. of Ind. Eng. &. Manage., Technion - Israel Inst. of Technol., Haifa, Israel
authors.name: Elena Leshchenko

details.abstract: A sequential probability ratio test (SPRT) is discussed, for comparison of two systems, one "basic" (b), and the other "new" (n), with exponentially distributed times between failures (TBF). The hypothesis that the mean TBF<sub>n</sub>/MTBF<sub>b</sub> ges 1 is checked, versus one that it is <1. The paper deals with tests with a low Average Sample Number (ASN), having the advantage of economy in time requirement, and cost; and it is shown that the points of possible solutions in them are sparse. Criteria are proposed for assessment of the test quality, with a view to optimization of its parameters. We present a search algorithm for the truncation apex (TA), with dependences for the search domain, and for the position of the oblique test boundaries, serving jointly as the basis for our development of the test planning algorithm.

citations.title: Comparison of the Mean Time Between Failures for Two Systems Under Short Tests

links.abstract: This study deals with simultaneous testing of two systems, one "basic" (subscript b), and the other "new" (n), both with an exponential distribution describing the times between failures. We test whether the mean TBF<sub>n</sub>/MTBF<sub>b</sub> ratio equals a given value, versus whether it is smaller than the given value. These tests yield a binomial pattern. A recursive algorithm calculates the probability of a given combination of failure numbers in the systems, permitting rapid, accurate det...

context.text: IN an earlier paper [1], a test was described for two systems: “basic” (subscript \$b\$), and “new” (subscript \$n\$), with an exponentially distributed time between failures.
The search for the solution involves iterative approximations [1], or the running of possible versions.

Its boundaries are demarcated [1] by two truncation lines parallel to the coordinate axes, and two oblique lines whose slope \$s\$ is determined using SPRT theory [2], depending only on \$d\$, and \$\Phi_{0}\$: The respective absolute terms \$h_{r}\$, and \$h_{a}\$ of the respective Reject, and Accept lines (oblique boundaries) in Fig. 2 depend on the parameters \$\alpha^{\ast}\$, and \$\beta^{\ast}\$: 

Fig. 2.
The given plan point \$(r_{b},r_{n})\$ in Fig. 2 can be hit from two adjoining points with probability [1]:where .
The probability \$P_{a}(\Phi)\$ is obtainable [1], [4] as the sum of those of hitting all ADP, \$P_{ADP}(r_{n},\Phi)\$: .
This circumstance makes for some difficulty in planning long tests [1], and becomes the main problem in short ones.
The measure chosen for the first criterion was \$R_{D}\$, the relative deviation of \$\alpha_{real}\$ and \$\beta_{real}\$ from the desired \$\alpha=\beta\$ [1]: .

Accordingly, the measure chosen for the second criterion was \$R_{ASN}\$, the relative excess of the ASN of the truncated test over its non-truncated counterpart [1]. where \$\Phi_{i}\$ is values of \$\Phi\$ forming the geometric progression .
As was shown in [1], at \$\alpha\approx\beta\$, a shift of the TA (Fig. 2) to the left of the centerline increases the \$ASN(\Phi)\$.

In tests with \$R_{ASN}<5\%\$, the truncation boundaries lie too far from the origin (Fig. 2) so that the truncation benefits are lost; in tests with \$R_{ASN}>10\%\$, the benefits are lost because of the steep increase of the ASN [1].

It was shown in [1] that, at \$\alpha=\beta\$, the truncation apex falls on the centerline, and dependences permitting determination of the \$TA_{n}\$ coordinate with high accuracy were found for \$d\leq 3\$.
The dependences appear considerably less smooth than those for \$d\leq 3\$ [1, Fig. 11].

of the mean time between failures for two systems
references.text: Y. H. Michlin, G. Grabarnik, "Sequential testing for comparison of the mean time between failures for two systems", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 56, no. 2, pp. 321-331, June 2007.

context.text: It was shown that this test reduces to the binomial SPRT [2].

Its boundaries are demarcated [1] by two truncation lines parallel to the coordinate axes, and two oblique lines whose slope \$s\$ is determined using SPRT theory [2], depending only on \$d\$, and \$\Phi_{0}\$: The respective absolute terms \$h_{r}\$, and \$h_{a}\$ of the respective Reject, and Accept lines (oblique boundaries) in Fig. 2 depend on the parameters \$\alpha^{\ast}\$, and \$\beta^{\ast}\$: 

Fig. 2.
A formula for it is obtainable as per [2, Section 5.5] in parametric form: where .

The non-truncated SPRT is known [2], [6] to be the optimal for \$\Phi_{0}\$, and \$\Phi_{1}\$; in other words, this test has the smallest \$ASN(\Phi_{0})\$, and \$ASN(\Phi_{1})\$, among all possible tests with the given \$\alpha/\beta\$ pair.
Except for special cases [2, Section 5.5], this formula does not yield the exact ASN for a real test, but is eminently suitable for purposes of comparison of the latter with the ideal one.

According to [9], the required number of failures should satisfy the relationship (in the notation of this paper) where \$F_{\alpha,2r_{n},2r_{b}}\$ is the inverse cumulative \$F\$-distribution function with \$2r_{n}\$ degrees of freedom in the numerator, and \$2r_{b}\$ in the denominator.
